awd_titl_txt: Support for US Astronomers to Attend International Scientific Conferences and the 30th IAU General Assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
Astronomy is a fully international endeavor; we all share the same sky. To participate in the international scientific community, American researchers must meet and collaborate with researchers from around the world. Every three years, the International Astronomical Union has a General Assembly accompanied by topical symposia, joint discussions, working groups, and business meetings. The next such meeting will be held in August 2018. In order to ensure a vigorous participation by the US astronomical community, this award will fund small travel grants to enable approximately 150 US astronomers to attend the General Assembly. This award will also provide small travel grants to approximately 50 US astronomers per year to attend various international meetings over the next 3 years.  Preference will be given to early-career astronomers and astronomers from less-endowed institutions. Scientists supported by this program will come from a wide range of educational institutions, museums, planetariums, etc. The experiences they gain from this meeting will be shared with a broad segment of the US population, exposing them to the global nature of astronomy and the importance of international collaboration to the advancement of science and technology.

The small travel grant program will be administered by the American Astronomical Society (AAS), the principal professional organization for US astronomers. They have very successfully and economically administered similar programs in the past, and the proposed procedures ensure that these funds will provide the maximum benefit to the astronomical community at minimal cost. The AAS will solicit proposals, select awardees, issue funds to be used for airfare only, collect receipts and meeting reports from the grantees, and prepare a final assessment and report on the entire program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant provided support for US astronomers and planetary scientists to attend international scientific conferences by providing reimbursement for round trip, economy class airfare to/from the meeting location.  Preference is given to early career astronomers or astronomers from smaller institutions.  If an applicant is playing a critical role at the conference, for example, giving a plenary lecture, they may also get a slight preference, even if they are a more senior astronomer or an astronomer at a larger institution.

This grant was originally received in 2018 and was meant to only support travel through 2020, however, the COVID-19 panedemic cancelled all international travel for a period of time, so we requested no-cost extensions from the NSF in order to support scientists as the pandemic waned and travel returned. 

In total, 178 grants were awarded for a total of $269,077.91.  Of this total, 33 individuals received support to travel to the 30th General Assembly of the IAU in Vienna Austria in August of 2018 and only four received funding for the 31st General Assembly meeting of the IAU in Busan, South Korea.  We expected more applicants for the Vienna meeting and were able to adjust our award budget to support additional non-IAU conferences  We also expected more people to attend the Busan conference, but the pandemic severely impacted the number of travellers applying.  We therefore were able to support additional travel beyond what was budgeted to non-IAU conferences.

The reason this grant is important is that astronomy is a fully international endeavor and US astronomers must network with, collaborate with and learn from astronomers in other countries.  The best way to do this is to attend focused and general scientific conferences that bring together astronomers from around the world for a week or so to share their results and build networks from which future research can emerge.  By focusing particularly on early-career astronomers the program helps enhance the careers of these researchers by allowing them to be noticed by and dialog with foreign researchers.  By focusing  on supporting scientists with fewer resources from their home institution, we allow connections to be formed that would otherwise be difficult or impossible to establish.  By supporting US astronomers who are playing a key role at a conference, we help spotlight US participation and research prowess on the international stage.

The AAS has supported US scientists over many decades utilizing these support fund from the National Science Foundation and we anticipate doing so in the future as well because we believe the program directly fulfills our mission to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe as a diverse and inclusive astronomical community. 

The submitted images are examples of US astronomers attending conferences or images of attendees at some significant international conferences of note.
